text:
Hi everybody. Thank you for having me with
you. My name is Emmelda and I have an interesting

news for you. What is it? Well, soon I will
be travelling to the United States of America,

but then I thought something that maybe interesting
for you as well. You know what? I often have

trouble with pronouncing certain words, when
I’m in the US, because they pronounce it

differently. So they have trouble understanding
me and I have trouble understanding them.

So I thought it would be a great idea, where
I can show you all the words and how they

are pronounced differently in both the UK
as well as the US.
So let’s get started

with the first word of the day is, Schedule.
Now the British pronunciation is, Sh, Shed-yul,

so it’s like shedding your clothes, so schedule,
however Americans pronounce this word as,

Sked-yul. So it is Sched-yul vs. Sked-yul.
The next word I have for you is, Often. Now

British pronounce this word as, Of-Un, however
Americans they stress on the “T” here

and they pronounce this word as Of-Tin, not
ten but tin so you can say, yes it’s not

often, its oftin. So its schedule, often.
Let’s move on to the third word, Herb. What

is a Herb? You see the green vegetables or
leafs that will help you or will become a

medication or a drug, that’s what the herb
is, it’s like its plants. However its pronounced

differently in these two countries, so herb
is pronounced the way it is pronounced or

spelt in British, which is, H-urb, so it is
herb, however while you’re in America, they

often drop the letter “H” and just pronounce
the Erb. So it becomes Erb, Herb vs. Erb.

Is that clear? Let’s move on to the complicated
ones, Is it Pri-vacie or is it Pr-I-vacy?

Well, the British pronounce this word as Pri-Vacie,
however the Americans stress on the “I”

and they say Pr-I-vacy, so its Pri-vacie and
Pr-I vacy. Similarly Vitamins vs. Vite-mins.

Vit-amins, they say, Vite-mins. So the pronunciation
or the stress is on I here, the difference

in the pronunciation is on I here. The next
most common, but most confused word is, Water.

Now British pronounce this word as W-aw-tuh,
so I’m gonna write as Water. Please note

my mouth or my lip movement, W-aw-tuh . Notice
the way my lip is becoming round, W-aw-tuh.

One thing that you may want to note is British
usually; do not pronounce the letter “R”

in their words. Maybe its Park or Water or
Car. They don’t pronounce the “R” as

much as the Americans do. So how does this
word water changes in W-aw-dder lets look?

So its W-aw-dder. What happens with American
pronunciation is., as soon as the alphabet

“T” falls between two vowels. The T becomes
D. So it becomes W-aw-dder vs. W-aw-tuh. You

saw the difference? Now let’s move on to
the next word, Identify. Now British pronounce

the way it is read or it is spelt I-den-ti-fy,
that is I-den-ti-fy. However Americans they

usually do not pronounce the letter T. How
would you pronounce the word then? It becomes

I-deni-fy . So its I-den-ti-fy vs. I-deni-fy.
We need your identification, so that’s how

an American would ask your any identity proof.
So its I-den-ti-fy vs. I-deni-fy. Moving on

to the next word is, Can you help me pronounce
it? Now some say its Gar-idge, some say as

Ga-rr-aage. So Gar-idge is British, Gar-idge.
It’s the same as Marriage or Cartilage,

the age becomes idge for British. However
the word –Garage is changed as Ga-rr-aage.

So it’s no more Gar- idge sale, it’s more
as a Ga-rr-aage sale in the US. And finally

the last but my favourite word of the day
is, Moh-bil or Moh-bile. American is Moh-bil,

some of the Americans don’t pronounce the
ile sound. Sometimes they pronounce it as,

so you can either say Moh-bil or Mo-bil. However
our dear British friends pronounce it as Moh,

so the stress is in the I here, Moh-bile and
Moh-bil. So friends you saw how different

pronunciation or how different people pronounce
the same words in the US or UK. I hope you

found this lesson extremely interesting as
well as useful. I will be back with another
one. Until then
see you. Good Bye.
